posts.name: Mike Garcia
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone!

We’d like to share the current version of our electrical layout diagram **. It showcases how we’ve organized subsystems, structured our CAN wiring, distributed power, and labeled components to improve maintainability and field troubleshooting.

Our key design goals were:

Clear subsystem separation

Simplified and reliable CAN topology (using a star-style breakout to subsystems)

Clean and traceable power paths

Field-friendly layout to support quick debugging

We’re proud of the result, but we’re very open to community feedback or suggestions . Whether it’s ideas for layout optimization, component choices, or wiring strategies—any insights are welcome and appreciated!

Wiring Diagram – Segmented CAN Bus line 1920×1180 158 KB

Wiring Diagram – Segmented CAN Bus line 1920×1180 158 KB

Wiring Diagram – Segmented CAN Bus line 1920×1180 158 KB

Thanks in advance for your time and support!

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
4 notes!

CAN Resistors should be 120Ω (you have 100Ω listed). Although 100Ω will probably work, the spec is 120Ω on each end of a CAN bus.

CAN Resistors should be 120Ω (you have 100Ω listed). Although 100Ω will probably work, the spec is 120Ω on each end of a CAN bus.

Make sure the CAN terminating resistor switch on the PDH is OFF given that you are terminating at the end of the CAN2.0 Bus that the PDH and RIO are both present for.

Make sure the CAN terminating resistor switch on the PDH is OFF given that you are terminating at the end of the CAN2.0 Bus that the PDH and RIO are both present for.

The REV Radio Power Module will not be allowed to power the VIVID-HOSTING radio in future years if this is a document looking forward. Wire to a weidmuller port channel on the PDH , and/or use a passive POE injector between the radio and RIO powered by those same ports on the PDH .

The REV Radio Power Module will not be allowed to power the VIVID-HOSTING radio in future years if this is a document looking forward. Wire to a weidmuller port channel on the PDH , and/or use a passive POE injector between the radio and RIO powered by those same ports on the PDH .

Minor layout thing: if you invert the battery polarity and swap its position with the main circuit breaker, you can avoid the large gauge wires crossing over eachother.

Minor layout thing: if you invert the battery polarity and swap its position with the main circuit breaker, you can avoid the large gauge wires crossing over eachother.

posts.name: Yuval Gur | Electronics & Software mentor
posts.cooked:
I really love how this diagram looks — great job! Out of curiosity, which software did you use to create it?

I don’t have many suggestions, but I might recommend tightening the layout a bit so it fills the page more effectively for printing.

If this is a specific robot layout, and app allows, it could be helpful to label each CAN component with its ID and indicate each CAN network name — this would be especially useful for debugging.

Also, consider adding your team’s branding and the robot’s name. A printed version of this could make a great display for your pit and would be a valuable asset for the electronics subteam when presenting to judges.

Keep up the great work!

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked:
This is an awesome diagram. I would love to know what you used to make it so that I could make one for our team. That being said, I had a few technical questions.

To terminate your superstructure CAN bus, wouldn’t it be much simpler to chain from the rio to your CAN distribution and finish at the PDH ? Doing this would let you terminate with the PDH ’s built-in resistor. Also, you should ideally be terminating with 120-ohm resistors either way.

Wouldn’t it be much simpler if you powered your radio directly with the Weidmuller ports, so you can eliminate the need for an RPM ?

How is your pigeon powered? I don’t see any power wires leading to it.

Shouldn’t your CANivore’s power have a 10A fuse instead of the 20A shown in the diagram? I thought you should fuse a device with 10A anytime 22 AWG is used.

If there’s any reason why you guys wire this way, then I’d love to hear it. We used to struggle with having enough MPM ports, and I thought splicing all your CANcoders into one port was a really interesting solution.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Even though it’s electrically equivalent, I would keep the black and red wires for the left-side and top-right CANCoders together.

posts.name: Chris Mounts
posts.cooked: Not sure what software OP used but we use Inkscape for these diagrams. I’ve attached ours that is a couple years out of date now. It’s based on an even older one that someone else made. One tip is that you can export SVG files from Onshape drawing views. This makes it easy to get the iconography for these diagrams.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
It would be good to indicate what the various components are. There are a variety of motors with integrated controllers and it is not clear if you are only one type or multiple types.

Add CAN addresses to the various devices.

If there are connectors in some of the wiring paths, it may be useful to show them on the drawing.

posts.name: Yuval Gur | Electronics & Software mentor
posts.cooked: Wow, that looks amazing! How did you add common FRC electrical symbols with the Inkscape editor? Did you create them yourself? This is my first experience with Inkscape, so I might be missing something obvious…

posts.name: Chris Mounts
posts.cooked: Some of the symbols were in the existing I copied. The others are out of Onshape. You make a shaded view on a 2D sheet then export it as an SVG. The SVG can be opened in Inkscape and used as an object.

posts.name: Mike Garcia
posts.cooked:
Hey folks!

Sorry for the delay, but we finally have an updated version of our electrical diagram

Wiring Diagram – Segmented CAN Bus line_V.2 1920×1242 164 KB

Wiring Diagram – Segmented CAN Bus line_V.2 1920×1242 164 KB

Wiring Diagram – Segmented CAN Bus line_V.2 1920×1242 164 KB

The diagram has been updated with many of the suggestions you all kindly provided — shoutout to Jwal , YuvalGur-2231 , elctrilica , sokoloff , Chris_Mounts and others for the helpful feedback!

We’re still looking to improve , and I’d like to share some background on the design choices we made:

This structure was inspired by Team SCREAM (4522) , whom we met at a regional in Oklahoma. They run two independent CAN networks , and we adopted a similar approach:

One network comes from the CANivore , where all swerve-related components — Kraken X60 motors, CANCoders, and Pigeon 2.0 — are connected in series .

As a small note: we chose to wire all the encoders in parallel , which helps free up ports on the Mini Power Module and lets us power all of them from just one output instead of two, which we’ve seen some teams do.

According to Team SCREAM, since encoders are sensing-only devices , they mainly need a consistent voltage , and current draw is minimal and stable, so wiring them in parallel is considered safe.

The second CAN line runs from the roboRIO to the “Serial” input , where we plan to use a CAN STAR device from Playing With Fusion ( link here ).

This will allow us to connect all of our subsystems (intake, elevator, shooter, etc.) in parallel.

The idea is that if one subsystem disconnects (e.g., intake motors), the others (like the elevator) can still function. We haven’t tested this setup thoroughly yet, so if anyone has experience with a similar config, we’d love to hear your thoughts.

On a related note , we’re wondering if each of these parallel CAN branches needs a 120 Ω termination resistor, or if a single one at the end of the main network is sufficient. Any insights would be appreciated!

We built the diagram using Lucidchart , with a bunch of custom SVG imports .

Most of the parts came from this GitHub repo: GitHub - belaw888/FRC-Fritzing-Parts

The rest… we made the old-school way with MS Paint (not ideal, but it got the job done).

Lucidchart worked well enough, though after importing a bunch of SVGs we had to pay around $10 USD . Some alignment quirks aside, it was a decent platform overall.

We’re still open to feedback or questions — keep it coming!

Thanks again, and cheers from Mexico!

love the diagram!!

Mike6170:

On a related note , we’re wondering if each of these parallel CAN branches needs a 120 Ω termination resistor, or if a single one at the end of the main network is sufficient. Any insights would be appreciated!

you should only have the terminating resistor at the end of the main branch and make sure your branches are <12’’ (30cm)

also a slight nitpick but your main breaker is currently on the negative side of the battery which is the wrong side

and another small thing you could have all of the can IDs on the motors to help programming team keep track

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Mike6170:

we chose to wire all the encoders in parallel , which helps free up ports on the Mini Power Module and lets us power all of them from just one output instead of two,

We have used these terminal blocks to distribute power to low current, low risk devices for several years now. Typically, we run one pair of wires from a low current PDH channel to one of these on a subpanel and distribute the power locally. We have also used similar ones with screw cage terminals.

16Amp AC/DC 2x12 Position Terminal Block Distribution Module: Amazon.com: Industrial & Scientific

$10.99

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: We used to run this same power distribution, but it came with the downside of having a single fuse for every device powered off of it. This gave us huge issues when a short originating from the PDH blew the port’s fuse and killed every CANcoder and sensor downstream. Our solution to the shortage of ports was to use these quick connect boards for Krakens that let us power a CANcoder off of it, and the board came with its other benefits too. We were able to switch to an MPM and give each device its own fuse.

link_counts.title: ReFire Quick Connect for Brushless Motor

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
If one requires independent protection per circuit, then one would have to use something like the REV Mini- PDH .

In the 3 years we have been using these terminal blocks, we have not had an issue with multiple circuits being disabled because of a blown fuse. The members of our electrical group were chosen for having demonstrated good workmanship so we do not expect, nor have we experienced,  short circuits due to poor workmanship. Thus we are only expecting the upstream fuse to provide protection against “extremely catastrophic events” such as intrusion inside our frame perimeter. As a matter of course, the majority of our control system components wiring are quite well protected so even a “casual frame perimeter intrusion” should not cause damage.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked:
The issue we faced was an internal short in the PDH ’s port, an issue caused not by a student’s poor workmanship but by faulty hardware.

I understand that setups like this function with quality work, I just believe that redundancy should be added whenever possible. There is always the possibility for something to go wrong and it’s better to be prepared than not

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Yes. What I described won’t help in that situation.

Learning how to identify and manage the various risks is one of the important things to learn in this program.

Were you able to identify the cause of the internal short? We had the same thing happen when some metal debris got inside our PDH .

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: The issue occurred during the peak of build season, so we never actually got around to diagnosing it; we just taped it off and got back to work. The PDH we used was on the older side, and we kept it aside for practice bot use only. I suspect something similar with metal debris or some sort of damage caused by overuse.

posts.name: Mike Garcia
posts.cooked:
Thanks a lot for the recommendations!

We’re definitely going to move the main breaker to the positive side of the battery — just out of curiosity, why exactly is it incorrect to wire it on the negative side? We’ve always connected it that way and haven’t had any issues during inspection, haha.

Also, we’ll make sure to keep the CAN branches under 12’’ and only terminate the end of the main trunk. Super helpful!

As for the CAN IDs, great call — that’s something we’ll definitely prioritize in the full robot diagram for the season. For now, we’re mostly trying to shape this new topology so we can walk the students through the concept, but it’ll absolutely be part of the finalized season layout.

Thanks again! Let us know if you catch anything else.

posts.name: Mike Garcia
posts.cooked:
elctrilica:

We used to run this same power distribution, but it came with the downside of having a single fuse for every device powered off of it. This gave us huge issues when a short originating from the PDH blew the port’s fuse and killed every CANcoder and sensor downstream. Our solution to the shortage of ports was to use these quick connect boards for Krakens that let us power a CANcoder off of it, and the board came with its other benefits too. We were able to switch to an MPM and give each device its own fuse.

Thanks so much! We’ll definitely keep that in mind.

We’re just curious — what specific advantages did you see from using those terminal boards? We’re still debating whether the investment is worth it given the cost. Also, we weren’t aware that this particular board was available from that supplier — it’s cheaper than the one WCP sells, but we’d love to hear what benefits you noticed when implementing it in your system.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Mike6170:

why exactly is it incorrect to wire it on the negative side? We’ve always connected it that way and haven’t had any issues during inspection

R609 dictates that the electrical system be connected as shown in Figure 8-8. Figure 8-8 shows the breaker on the positive wire. There’s no electrical reason for it to break the positive instead of breaking the negative, but the rule IMO clearly requires breaking the positive.
